title: POLITICAL INSTABILITY IN PERSIAN ANATOLIA One of the most important (and frequently neglected) aspects of Philip II's plans for an intervention in Asia is the instability of Persian rule in Asia Minor. In an outgrowth of his University of California dissertation, The So-Called "Great Satraps' Revolt," 366-60 B.C.: Concerning Local Instability in the Achaemenid Far West

Michael Weiskopf argues that the ancient sources incorrectly describe a general, well-organized threat to Achaemenid rule. He sees instead an instability resulting from a series of local Anatolian satrapal squabbles
